title: 108_hr4209
content: The "Idling Reduction Tax Credit Act of 2004" is cited as the short title. It introduces the Idling Reduction Tax Credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, providing a credit for reducing idling. The Idling Reduction Tax Credit Act of 2004 introduces a tax credit for qualifying idling reduction devices installed on heavy-duty diesel-powered vehicles, covering 50% of the costs incurred, up to a maximum of $3,500 per device. The Idling Reduction Tax Credit Act of 2004 offers a tax credit for idling reduction devices on heavy-duty diesel-powered vehicles, covering 50% of costs up to $3,500 per device. The devices must reduce long-duration idling at rest stops or stationary locations. The term 'heavy-duty diesel-powered on-highway vehicle' refers to vehicles used for transportation on highways, while 'long-duration idling' is the operation of a main drive engine for over 15 minutes without engaging in gear. The Idling Reduction Tax Credit Act of 2004 provides a tax credit for idling reduction devices on such vehicles, covering 50% of costs up to $3,500 per device. The Idling Reduction Tax Credit Act of 2004 provides a tax credit for idling reduction devices on heavy-duty diesel-powered on-highway vehicles. The basis of the property is reduced by the amount of the credit determined, and no other deductions or credits are allowed. Taxpayers can elect not to claim the credit for a taxable year. The credit is part of the general business credit under section 38 of the tax code. The Idling Reduction Tax Credit Act of 2004 provides a tax credit for idling reduction devices on heavy-duty diesel-powered on-highway vehicles. The table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the tax code is amended to include the idling reduction tax credit under section 45G(a). The Idling Reduction Tax Credit Act of 2004 offers a tax credit for idling reduction devices on heavy-duty diesel vehicles. Section 45G is amended to include this credit, and the Secretary of Energy determines certification standards for these devices. The effective date for these amendments is after December 31, 2003. The Secretary of Energy, in consultation with relevant agencies, will publish standards for certifying idling reduction devices to reduce air pollution and fuel consumption under section 45G of the Internal Revenue Code.
